instruction: How were the machine learning models utilized in the study on the feasibility of macronutrient level classification in oil palm crops using Landsat-8 imageries and Machine Learning (ML)?
Output:
In the study, machine learning models were used to classify macronutrient levels in oil palm crops using Landsat-8 imageries and Machine Learning (ML). The researchers applied variable rates of compost and inorganic fertilizer to experimental plots and studied the levels of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), magnesium (Mg), and calcium (Ca). 

To classify the macronutrient levels, the researchers acquired spectral features for each plot using image filters, separability metrics, vegetation indices (VI), and feature selection techniques. These spectral features were then used as input data for the machine learning models.

The models were calibrated and validated with 30 repetitions, and the best mean overall accuracy was reported for nitrogen (N) and potassium (K) levels at 79.7 +/- 4.3% and 76.6 +/- 4.1% respectively. However, the accuracies for phosphorus (P), magnesium (Mg), and calcium (Ca) levels could not be accurately classified due to limitations in the dataset used.

The study highlighted the effectiveness of separability metrics in quantifying class separability and the importance of vegetation indices for nitrogen (N) and potassium (K) level classification.
